title: Srimad Bhagavatam | HG Chanchalapathi Dasa | SB 1.7.34 | 21-02-2016
speaker: HG Chanchalapathi Dasa

segments.key_quote: Because he is absolute, both his anger and pleasure are the same.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that while both Arjuna and Krishna are described as angry, Krishna's anger is transcendental and not subject to material nature.

segments.key_quote: Srila Prabhupada is taking this as an opportunity to explain that Arjuna's anger was that his eyes were red. Krishna is also angry that his eyes are like lotus.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the context of Ashwatthama's capture and how Srila Prabhupada uses the situation to explain the difference between Arjuna's and Krishna's anger.

segments.key_quote: Krishna's position, Krishna's personality, Krishna's form, Krishna's nature, Krishna's name, Krishna's activities, all of these are transcendental.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the transcendental nature of Krishna, contrasting it with the material world composed of Panchabhootas (five elements) and influenced by Kala (time).

segments.key_quote: Krishna's position is Tamasaha Parastaat. Tamasaha refers to the material world, the Panchabhootas under the time.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Krishna's transcendental position using references from the Bhagavad Gita, particularly focusing on how Krishna establishes this in the fourth chapter by stating he spoke yoga to Vivasvan long ago.

segments.key_quote: Arjuna is asking, Krishna, you are saying that you spoke this knowledge to Vivasvan. How could you do that?
segments.summary: The speaker explains Arjuna's doubt about Krishna's claim of teaching yoga to Vivasvan, questioning how Krishna, being younger, could have instructed someone so senior.

segments.key_quote: Prabhu, how could you give Bhagavad Gita to Jawaharlal Nehru, your junior? Jawaharlal Nehru, Gandhiji, they are very senior. How could you give?
segments.summary: The speaker uses an analogy of distributing Bhagavad Gitas to Jawaharlal Nehru, Mahatma Gandhi, and Dr. Radhakrishnan to illustrate Arjuna's question about how Krishna could have taught Vivasvan.

segments.key_quote: Many, many births, I have taken... I am aware of all of those different appearances of mine, you don't understand, you don't remember them.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Krishna's answer to Arjuna, emphasizing the difference between them: Krishna remembers his past lives and is unborn and inexhaustible, while Arjuna does not.

segments.key_quote: Situated in his transcendental position, he comes to this world.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Krishna's appearance in the world, using the analogy of a king visiting a prison to distribute sweets, and connects it to Krishna's purpose of protecting devotees, annihilating demons, and establishing dharma.

segments.key_quote: After we give up this body, we will not take another birth. Liberated.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that understanding Krishna's transcendental nature and activities leads to liberation from the cycle of birth and death, emphasizing the practical benefit of this knowledge.

segments.key_quote: This knowledge has an ability to help us come out of all of these problems.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the pervasive anxiety in the material world, citing examples from politics, global issues, and personal lives, and asserts that Krishna consciousness can help overcome these problems.

segments.key_quote: Wake up. And I wake up and I say, oh. There is no leopard. There is no one dozen leopards, there is no one leopard, nothing. It was all a dream.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a dream where he is chased by a leopard and finds himself in a room full of leopards to illustrate the anxiety of material existence and how waking up from the dream brings relief.

segments.key_quote: Material existence is actually a dream... Each one of us being his part and parcel are also transcendental.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that material existence is like a dream, and that we are all transcendental beings belonging to Krishna's world, but are currently absorbed in material energy.

segments.key_quote: Out of compassion for us, Krishna has presented Veda Purana... So he sends his own representatives.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Krishna sends his representatives, like Balarama and Nithyananda Prabhu, to make knowledge about Krishna available in the world, as we cannot figure it out ourselves.

themes: Solving problems vs. getting out of problems
segments.key_quote: We don't solve the problems, because problems cannot be solved, we get out of the problem.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a heated debate on television to illustrate the blazing fire of material existence and emphasizes Prabhupada's teaching that we should get out of problems rather than trying to solve them.

segments.key_quote: With the help of the Vedic literatures, with the help of the spiritual master, who explains this knowledge, and if we take it seriously, we can find relief, we can get out of these problems.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the importance of the spiritual master, Vedic literatures, and Srila Prabhupada's compassion in helping us find relief from material problems, and thanks the audience for their book distribution efforts.
